verses.text: As Jesus was leaving the temple, one of his disciples said to him, 'Teacher, look what massive stones and magnificent buildings!'
verses.comment: The disciples are amazed at the beauty and strength of the temple, a central place for Jewish worship, foreshadowing its spiritual fulfillment in Christ (John 2:19).

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Do you see these great buildings? Not one stone will be left upon another; every one will be thrown down.'
verses.comment: Jesus prophesies the destruction of the temple, fulfilled in 70 AD. This reveals God’s new plan to dwell with his people through Christ’s body, the Church (see John 2:19-21, Eph. 2:20-22).

verses.text: While he was sitting on the Mount of Olives across from the temple, Peter, James, John, and Andrew asked him privately,
verses.comment: These four disciples, among Jesus' closest companions, seek a deeper understanding of the coming events. The Mount of Olives is a significant place of prophecy (Ezek. 11:23; Zech. 14:4).

verses.text: 'Tell us, when will these things happen, and what will be the sign that all these things are about to be accomplished?'
verses.comment: The disciples ask two questions: the timing and the sign of the end. This shows their expectation of both a literal and spiritual fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: Then Jesus began to say to them, 'See that no one leads you astray.'
verses.comment: Jesus warns of the danger of false teaching. Staying true to apostolic doctrine is essential for the life of the Church (see Acts 2:42).

verses.text: 'Many will come in my name, saying, “I am he,” and they will lead many astray.'
verses.comment: Here Jesus predicts false messiahs and deceptive leaders. This shows the Church must discern truth from error with the guidance of the Spirit (1 John 4:1).

verses.text: 'When you hear of wars and rumors of wars, do not be troubled. Such things must happen, but the end is not yet.'
verses.comment: Jesus distinguishes ongoing turmoil from the final end. The Church lives in hope and trust even during tribulation, awaiting Christ’s return.

verses.text: 'Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. There will be earthquakes in various places; there will also be famines. These are the beginning of birth pains.'
verses.comment: These events echo Old Testament language of judgment and hope (Isaiah 66:7-9), indicating spiritual renewal through trial.

verses.text: 'But be on your guard. For they will deliver you over to councils, and you will be beaten in synagogues. You will stand before governors and kings for my sake, to bear witness before them.'
verses.comment: Early Christians faced persecution. Their suffering for Christ is seen as a participation in Jesus’ own passion and the ongoing witness of the Church.

verses.text: 'And the gospel must first be preached to all the nations.'
verses.comment: The spread of the gospel to all nations fulfills the promise to Abraham (Gen. 12:3; Gal. 3:8). The Church’s mission is universal and apostolic.

verses.text: 'Whenever they lead you away and hand you over, do not worry beforehand about what you will say. Say whatever is given to you in that hour, for it is not you who speak, but the Holy Spirit.'
verses.comment: Jesus promises the Holy Spirit’s guidance to the apostles, showing the ongoing inspiration and authority of their witness.

verses.text: 'Brother will betray brother to death, and a father his child. Children will rise up against parents and have them put to death.'
verses.comment: Persecution disrupts families, as seen in prophetic texts. The call to discipleship surpasses even natural ties (cf. Luke 14:26).

verses.text: 'And you will be hated by all for my name’s sake. But the one who endures to the end will be saved.'
verses.comment: Enduring to the end is necessary for salvation. This endurance is understood as persevering in faith and fidelity, not a one-time act.

verses.text: 'But when you see the abomination of desolation standing where he should not be (let the reader understand), then let those in Judea flee to the mountains.'
verses.comment: A direct reference to Daniel, indicating a sacrilegious act in the temple. Such warnings show the need to heed true interpretation of Scripture and Tradition.

verses.text: 'The one on the housetop must not go down nor enter his house to take anything out.'
verses.comment: Urgency in fleeing reminds believers to be always ready, not attached to possessions when persecution comes.

verses.text: 'And the one in the field must not turn back to get his cloak.'
verses.comment: Hastening away, without even a cloak, emphasizes total trust in God and detachment from worldly security.

verses.text: 'Woe to those who are pregnant and to those nursing babies in those days!'
verses.comment: The prophecy highlights the intensity and difficulty of coming tribulation; God’s mercy is evident in His concern for the vulnerable.

verses.text: 'Pray that it may not happen in winter.'
verses.comment: Jesus instructs prayer for divine intervention even in times of distress, showing God’s sovereignty is to be actively sought in all circumstances.

verses.text: 'For those days will be a time of tribulation such as has not happened since the beginning of creation, which God created, until now, nor ever will be.'
verses.comment: This unparalleled tribulation echoes apocalyptic literature. Faithful endurance and hope in God’s ultimate plan are essential.

verses.text: 'And if the Lord had not cut short the days, no one would be saved. But for the sake of the elect, whom he has chosen, he has shortened the days.'
verses.comment: The elect are preserved by God’s providence. This reflects the Church’s doctrine of God’s sustaining grace for the faithful remnant.

verses.text: 'Then if anyone says to you, “Look, here is the Christ!” or, “Look, there he is!” do not believe it.'
verses.comment: Disciples are cautioned against false claims of Messiah’s return. True faith discerns Christ in the fullness of his coming, not in false expectations.

verses.text: 'For false christs and false prophets will arise and perform signs and wonders, to lead astray, if possible, even the elect.'
verses.comment: Even the elect can be tempted, emphasizing the need for the Church’s stable guidance and discernment through Tradition and the Spirit.

verses.text: 'But be on guard; I have told you everything ahead of time.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ prophetic warning gives the Church the ability to prepare and remain faithful in the face of hardship.

verses.text: 'But in those days, after that tribulation, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light,'
verses.comment: Apocalyptic imagery signals cosmic upheaval and the decisive intervention of God in human history.

verses.text: 'and the stars will be falling from the sky, and the powers that are in the heavens will be shaken.'
verses.comment: The shaking of the heavens symbolizes the end of the present order and the coming of Christ’s kingdom.

verses.text: 'Then they will see the Son of Man coming in the clouds with great power and glory.'
verses.comment: This is a direct claim of Jesus’ divinity, fulfilling the prophecy of Daniel about the Son of Man’s eternal rule. The Church’s hope is Christ’s visible, glorious return.

verses.text: 'And then he will send out the angels, and gather together his elect from the four winds, from the ends of the earth to the ends of the heavens.'
verses.comment: The angels gather the elect, a symbol of the Church’s unity which transcends all nations and eras, pointing toward the final gathering of the faithful.

verses.text: 'From the fig tree, learn this parable: As soon as its branch becomes tender and puts forth its leaves, you know that summer is near.'
verses.comment: Jesus uses the fig tree to teach spiritual sensitivity to the signs of the times and the unfolding of God’s plan through history.

verses.text: 'So also, when you see these things happening, you know that he is near, at the very gates.'
verses.comment: The nearness of Christ calls for vigilance and readiness among all believers.

verses.text: 'Truly, I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all these things take place.'
verses.comment: “Generation” can refer to Jesus’ contemporaries or symbolically to the age of the Church, pointing to both immediate and ongoing fulfillment.

verses.text: 'Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims divine authority for his teaching, underscoring the permanence of his word above even creation.

verses.text: 'But concerning that day or that hour, no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father.'
verses.comment: The mystery of Christ's return calls for continual watchfulness. Jesus, in his human nature, voluntarily does not claim this knowledge, pointing to his humility and the mystery of the Incarnation.

verses.text: 'Be on guard, keep awake. For you do not know when the time will come.'
verses.comment: Constant spiritual vigilance is the hallmark of faithful discipleship, calling all believers to active, persevering faith.

verses.text: 'It is like a man going on a journey, who, when he leaves home, puts his servants in charge, each with his assigned work, and commands the doorkeeper to stay alert.'
verses.comment: Christ entrusts his household—the Church—to its leaders and members, each with a vocation to serve faithfully until his return.

verses.text: 'Therefore, stay awake—for you do not know when the master of the house will come, whether in the evening, or at midnight, or when the rooster crows, or in the morning—'
verses.comment: The return of Christ can happen at any time; Christians are called to readiness at all hours. This reinforces the call to persevere in faith and practice.

verses.text: 'lest he come suddenly and find you asleep.'
verses.comment: Spiritual slumber means neglecting one’s duties in the Church and faith, resulting in tragic consequences at the Lord’s return.

verses.text: 'And what I say to you I say to all: Stay awake.'
verses.comment: The universal call to vigilance is for all believers, both clergy and laity, highlighting the collective responsibility to remain faithful and alert, awaiting Christ’s coming.
